The spread of Greek civilization¹ in Asia Minor and Syria was due in the first instance to the conquests of Alexander; but of all that he did nothing is so truly a monument of his greatness as the city² of Alexandria. Ile knew that he had found a site for a great and wealthy port, and the result 111016 than sulfilled his expectation. Here were wrought out the most solid achievements of the Greek mind, those of the mathematicians3 whose astonishing progress in many sciences formed a starting-point for the great advances of modern times, Here too in the days of the Roman Empire was one of the chief seats of the theologistic Christianity⁴ of the East.
